newsitem.title: CANADA: Alcan sees '97 aluminum demand up by 3 pct.
newsitem.headline: Alcan sees '97 aluminum demand up by 3 pct.

text.p: Alcan Aluminium Ltd president and chief executive officer Jacques Bougie said on Thursday that he expects global aluminum demand to increase by three percent in 1997.
"We anticipate that demand will increase by about three percent for 1997, even if year-to-date demand has increased about 10 percent," Bougie told reporters after the company's annual meeting.
Bougie said demand jumped in the first quarter over the year earlier quarter mainly because customers are restocking aluminum in the face of higher aluminum prices.

Bougie said his growth estimate is conservative, but he declined to make a specific forecast on aluminum prices or net profits for 1997. Every US$100-a-tonne fluctuation in the price of aluminum translates into a US$100 million impact on Alcan's net profits, he said.
In its first quarter ended March 31, Alcan earned a net profit of US$143 million or US$0.62 a share, up from a profit of US$125 million or US$0.53 a share in the year earlier quarter.

In his speech to the annual meeting, Bougie said Alcan is not yet at the decision stage on a number of proposed projects. Those include a new 370,000-tonne smelter in Alma, Quebec, a new bauxite mine in Australia, a possible joint venture 240,000-tonne smelting and power project in China, and participation in the partial privatizaition of the aluminum industry in Venezuela.

But Bougie said Alcan has the financial capability to proceed with all the projects at once, if needed, in addition to the US$350 million expansion of the company's Pindamonhangaba aluminum sheet rolling facility in Brazil announced two days ago.
"We could do Alma, Venezuela, Ely bauxite in Australia and Pinda' without a problem. All of them," Bougie said.
"We have a very strong balance sheet. We also have a US$1 billion credit line that was lined up last year," he said.
"On top of that, if an attractive acquisition came our way, we would not hesitate. The financial means of Alcan would not be what would stop us, actually," Bougie said.

Turning to Alcan's lawsuit against the British Columbia government seeking compensation for the government's cancellation of its Kemano Completion Project in 1995, Bougie said he sent a letter to B.C. Premier Glen Clark saying the company would be amenable to an out-of-court settlement. Bougie said he had not heard back from the premier.
Alcan is seeking compensation for the project, which would have added to its hydro-electric generating capacity in the province. Alcan took a US$420 million writedown on the project in 1995.
